questions.text: A 70-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his granddaughter for evaluation after a fall. According to the granddaughter, the patient has appeared confused for the past week. Today, when he tried to stand up from bed, he lost balance and fell to the floor. The patient was diagnosed with Lewy body dementia 2 weeks ago and started on carbidopa-levodopa, haloperidol, and rivastigmine. Temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 102/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mmHg in supine position and 90/60 mmHg in standing position. The patient is oriented to person, but not time or place. Physical examination reveals rigidity in both upper and lower extremities, which is notably worse than on previous examinations. The remainder of the neurological examination is within normal limits. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient with Lewy body dementia presents with acute worsening of confusion, muscle rigidity, and autonomic dysfunction (orthostatic hypotension) shortly after being prescribed haloperidol. These findings are suggestive of antipsychotic hypersensitivity.

Typical antipsychotic agents such as haloperidol work by antagonizing dopamine D2 receptors and can be used to treat severe agitation in patients with delirium. However, high-potency typical antipsychotics should be avoided in patients with Parkinson’s disease or Lewy body dementia. This contraindication exists since these conditions are caused by dopamine pathway dysfunction, which would be exacerbated by high-potency typical antipsychotics given their mechanism of action.

As a result, haloperidol and other high-potency typical antipsychotics should be avoided in patients with these conditions.  

Option Analysis

❌ Progression of disease:
Incorrect: Although rigidity and cognitive function may worsen over the course of Lewy body dementia, this patient’s acute decompensation and orthostatic hypotension are more suggestive of antipsychotic hypersensitivity.  
✅ Antipsychotic hypersensitivity:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Carbidopa-levodopa:
Incorrect: Although carbidopa-levodopa can lead to confusion and orthostatic hypotension, an increase in muscle rigidity would not be seen. In contrast, this patient’s acute decompensation and orthostatic hypotension are more suggestive of antipsychotic hypersensitivity.  
❌ Vitamin B12 deficiency:
Incorrect: Vitamin B12 deficiency presents with megaloblastic anemia and posterior spinal column deficits. Neurologically, the condition can present with paresthesias, spastic paresis, and gait ataxia. Symptoms develop gradually over the course of months to years, as opposed to weeks.  
❌ Neuroleptic malignant syndrome:
Incorrect: Neuroleptic malignant syndrome is characterized by confusion, coma, agitation, muscle rigidity, autonomic instability, and hyperthermia. It is a life-threatening emergency. This patient does not have hyperthermia and the acute exacerbation of his symptoms is more suggestive of antipsychotic hypersensitivity.

questions.text: A 29-year-old man present to his psychiatrist's office for a scheduled follow-up visit. The patient has a history of schizoaffective disorder, bipolar type, that was diagnosed during a recent admission to the local psychiatric inpatient unit. The patient was discharged from the unit on aripiprazole, which he reports adequately controls his psychiatric symptoms. However, he has developed muscle stiffness and intermittent neck spasms on the right and difficulty rotating his head. Temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), pulse is 60/min, respirations are 16/minute, and blood pressure is 130/75 mmHg. Physical examination shows an adult who appears his stated age and is calm and cooperative. Musculoskeletal exam reveals mild discomfort and muscle spasm at the right neck and limited rotation of the neck during active and passive range of motion testing, The patient’s head stays in a neutral position at rest. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient experiencing neck muscle stiffness and spasms that began shortly after starting an antipsychotic medication is having a dystonic reaction. An anticholinergic medication, such as benztropine or diphenhydramine, is the most appropriate treatment for the acute management of dystonia.

Dystonic reactions (i.e., dyskinesias) are reversible extrapyramidal symptoms that develop shortly after starting medications that block dopamine receptors. Dopamine blockade can cause involuntary muscle contractions, leading to abnormal muscle stiffness and difficulty relaxing the affected muscles. Dystonic reactions range in severity and can include torticollis, oculogyric crisis, and opisthotonos. These reactions are more common with the use of first-generation antipsychotics. However, even second-generation antipsychotics like aripiprazole, which are partial agonists of dopamine receptors, increase the risk of extrapyramidal symptoms.  

Patients with dystonia should be given an anticholinergic medication, like benztropine or diphenhydramine, for symptom management. Patients with mild dystonia may respond well to oral anticholinergic medication, while more severe cases, such as in patients experiencing oculogyric crisis, may require intravenous (IV) or intramuscular (IM) administration. The most effective way to reduce the risk of future dystonic reactions is to switch to an alternative medication with a lower risk of extrapyramidal symptoms.    

Option Analysis

✅ Benztropine:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Propranolol:
Incorrect: Propranolol is effective for movement disorders such as akathisia or tremor. However, this patient’s recent initiation of aripiprazole and muscle stiffness and spasm is consistent with a dystonic reaction. An anticholinergic medication like benztropine is the appropriate treatment. 
❌ Bromocriptine:
Incorrect: While bromocriptine may help treat certain types of dystonia, an anticholinergic medication, such as benztropine, is a better initial choice for this patient.  
❌ Donepezil :
Incorrect: Donepezil, an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor, is primarily used for treating patients with Alzheimer disease. This patient is experiencing a dystonic reaction from aripiprazole, and an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor could worsen symptoms. An anticholinergic medication, such as benztropine, is the best treatment.  
❌ Valbenazine :
Incorrect: Valbenazine is used to treat tardive dyskinesia, a condition characterized by sudden, involuntary movements of the face or body that can develop months or years after the initiation of antipsychotic therapy. This patient’s symptoms are more consistent with a dystonic reaction, for which an anticholinergic medication, such as benztropine, is appropriate.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to the physician due to loss of vision and pain in her right eye which began yesterday. In addition, she also feels numbness in her left hand. Last year, the patient presented with left-sided weakness. Three years ago, the patient also had an episode of severe eye pain accompanied with ataxia. Both times, the patient was successfully treated with steroids. Neuroimaging revealed well-defined areas of demyelination in the central nervous system. The physician decides that in addition to corticosteroids, he will start the patient on Natalizumab. Which of the following is a potential adverse effect of natalizumab?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with multiple neurological deficits separated in space and time in addition to neuroimaging consistent with relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis. First-line treatment of multiple sclerosis is steroids during acute attacks; however, natalizumab is another approved treatment shown to have a significant benefit in patients with relapsing-remitting MS.

Natalizumab is a monoclonal antibody that can be used in the treatment of multiple sclerosis and Crohn's disease. In multiple sclerosis patients, natalizumab has been shown to slow the progression of symptoms and decrease the rate of relapse in patients with relapsing-remitting courses.

Natalizumab is a monoclonal antibody against alpha-4-integrin receptors on endothelial cells lining blood vessels. Integrins are a class of selective adhesion molecules that are involved in the chemotaxis of leukocytes to the site of inflammation. Normally, leukocytes bind the integrins and then migrate from blood vessels to the site of inflammation. By blocking the integrins, natalizumab causes anti-inflammatory effects by inhibiting the leukocytes from migrating to the site of inflammation and inducing a proinflammatory response. In the brain, natalizumab blocks alpha4-beta1 integrins, preventing leukocytes from crossing the blood-brain barrier and entering the CNS, which is how it decreases inflammation in multiple sclerosis patients.

One of the major limitations of the use of natalizumab is the increased risk of reactivation of JC virus. JC virus is an opportunistic pathogen that resides in the oligodendrocytes in the brain. When the immune system is suppressed, such as in HIV or with natalizumab use, JC virus can get reactivated, leading to a disease known as progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML). PML is characterized by demyelination in the CNS due to the destruction of oligodendrocytes and is rapidly progressive and fatal. Therefore, patients taking natalizumab should be tested for anti-JC virus antibodies before starting treatment and continue to be tested periodically while on natalizumab, even if the initial anti-JC antibodies were negative.

Other side effects of natalizumab include headaches and nausea. In some patients, nucleated erythrocytes can appear in the peripheral blood, which has no clinical significance and usually disappear after stopping the treatment.  

Option Analysis

✅ Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Osmotic demyelination syndrome:
Incorrect: Osmotic demyelination syndrome is a fatal condition that results from rapid correction of hyponatremia. It is not associated with natalizumab use.  
❌ Hepatotoxicity:
Incorrect: Natalizumab is not associated with hepatotoxicity.  
❌ Cardiotoxicity:
Incorrect: Natalizumab does not cause cardiotoxicity. Trastuzumab, a monoclonal antibody against Her2-Neu receptors in the breast and is used with breast cancer, can sometimes lead to cardiotoxicity.  
❌ Lymphoma:
Incorrect: Lymphoma has been documented as side effects of anti-TNF antibodies, which are monoclonal antibodies that block the action of TNF. However, natalizumab is not associated with increased risk of lymphoma.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old man comes to the physician complaining of numbness in the upper extremities that started several days ago. The patient has no significant past medical history, but he did have an episode of trigeminal neuralgia 4 months ago, which resolved spontaneously. He does not have any urinary incontinence, but he mentions that he took fiber supplements last year due to several weeks of constipation that “resolved on its own.” Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 82/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 125/75 mmHg. Physical examination shows decreased vibratory and positional sensation in both upper extremities but no other sensory loss. An MRI is performed and shows the following:  


 Image reproduced from Radiopedia

Which of the following medications is likely to prevent future exacerbations of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with various neurological dysfunctions (e.g., paresthesias, constipation, trigeminal neuralgia) over the past year that have all resolved spontaneously. Taking into account the MRI scan, which demonstrates multiple periventricular plaques, he likely has multiple sclerosis (MS).  

Three therapeutic categories are used in the treatment of MS:  

1) Prevention of exacerbations with disease-modifying drugs (DMDs). All patients with relapsing-remitting MS should begin treatment with DMDs as soon as possible to prevent further exacerbations and slow the disease process. DMDs include interferon-beta, glatiramer acetate, alemtuzumab, and natalizumab. The initial choice of a specific DMD should be individualized according to disease activity and risk of adverse effects.  
2) Limiting the severity and duration of an acute MS attack. First-line treatment for acute exacerbations is high-dose glucocorticoid therapy. If the patient’s symptoms fail to improve, plasma exchange should be considered.
3) Supportive therapy aimed at improving or eliminating the various clinical complaints. This therapy includes medications that treat spasticity (e.g. baclofen), paresthesias (e.g., carbamazepine, amitriptyline), and concurrent psychiatric conditions (e.g., SSRIs, SNRIs).

Option Analysis

✅ Glatiramer acetate:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Baclofen:
Incorrect: Baclofen is a GABA receptor agonist that acts within the central nervous system. Although it is commonly used in patients with multiple sclerosis (MS) to treat muscle spasticity, it is not a disease-modifying drug and would therefore not prevent future attacks. 
❌ High-dose glucocorticoids:
Incorrect: Acute attacks of MS are treated with high-dose methylprednisolone. Corticosteroids have various immunosuppressive properties (e.g. induction of T-cell apoptosis). Given Th1 cells initiate the demyelinating episodes, corticosteroids would therefore be helpful during acute flares. However, the medication would not prevent future exacerbations. 
❌ Plasmapheresis :
Incorrect: Plasmapheresis can be used in patients with acute exacerbations of MS who do not respond to glucocorticoid therapy. Plasmapheresis involves removal of blood plasma and then reinfusion; this procedure may reduce the number of antibodies against myelin. However, plasmapheresis is not effective in reducing future MS relapses.
❌ Carbamazepine:
Incorrect: Carbamazepine can be used to treat painful paresthesias in patients with MS. Brain lesions can cause pain and paresthesia in the face, trunk, and limbs. Although helpful for symptomatic treatment, carbamazepine is unlikely to prevent the recurrence of future attacks in patients with MS.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman comes to the office to evaluate intermittent painful double vision for three days. Her symptoms occur only when looking laterally. The patient has myopia and has been wearing corrective lenses for ten years. Ten days ago, the patient fell off her bike and was seen in the emergency department. During that visit, a head CT scan was performed and was unremarkable. Current medications include oral contraceptive pills. Vitals are within normal limits. On examination, the pupils are equal and reactive to light. Corrected visual acuity is 20/40 in each eye. The left eye abducts with attempted left gaze, but the right eye remains stationary. The right eye abducts and exhibits horizontal nystagmus with a rightward gaze, but the left eye remains stationary. The patient can converge both eyes without associated nystagmus. Fundoscopy reveals bilateral disc hyperemia. Injury to which of the following structures is the most likely etiology of this patient's ocular symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with characteristic adduction defects of internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO) and hyperemia of the optic discs. Together, these findings indicate optic neuritis, one of the most common initial findings of multiple sclerosis (MS).

INO is a disorder of conjugate horizontal gaze. The affected eye cannot adduct, and the contralateral eye abducts with nystagmus; however, convergence and pupillary light reflexes are preserved. This condition is secondary to demyelination of the medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF), which normally mediates communication between the CN III (oculomotor) and CN VI (abducens) nuclei to allow for coordinated horizontal eye movements. Unilateral MLF lesions often result from lacunar strokes in the pontine artery distribution, whereas bilateral MLF lesions are typically observed in patients with MS.  



Option Analysis

❌ Oculomotor nerve  :
Incorrect: Damage to the oculomotor nerve (CN III) leaves the actions of the lateral rectus and the superior oblique muscle unopposed, resulting in an abducted and depressed eye (“down and out”). Ptosis and mydriasis are often seen as well.  
❌ Medial lemniscus  :
Incorrect: A lesion of the medial lemniscus would result in contralateral loss of vibration, proprioception, and light touch.  
✅ Medial longitudinal fasciculus  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Dorsal midbrain  :
Incorrect: Damage to the dorsal midbrain can cause Parinaud syndrome, with impaired upgaze and dilated non-reactive pupils. Moreover, Parinaud syndrome is most commonly seen in patients with hydrocephalus or posterior midbrain lesions (e.g. pineal tumors); trauma is an infrequent cause of Parinaud syndrome.  
❌ Abducens nerve:
Incorrect: Abducens nerve damage results in isolated lateral rectus palsy and an inability to abduct the eye.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman comes to the physician due to slurred speech and difficulty swallowing. The patient’s symptoms started two weeks ago and have progressively worsened. In addition, she has noticed excessive drooling and difficulty chewing food. She was seen five years ago due to painful eye movements, decreased vision in the left eye, and associated left lower extremity weakness. She was started on a monoclonal antibody, which helped control her symptoms, but she later stopped using it due to the adverse effects. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals brisk jaw reflexes bilaterally and an exaggerated gag reflex. The patient bursts out into spontaneous laughter on multiple occasions during the encounter. Which of the following is most likely responsible for this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Demyelination of the bilateral corticobulbar tracts
Tumor affecting the bilateral nucleus ambiguus
Tumor affecting the right nucleus ambiguus
Demyelination of the distal aspect cranial nerve IX

questions.solution:
Pseudobulbar palsy is an upper motor neuron lesion involving the corticobulbar (supranuclear) pathways of cranial nerves IX, X, and XI. An upper motor neuron lesion occurs above the motor nuclei of the cranial nerves. Pseudobulbar palsy is caused by bilateral damage to the corticobulbar tracts. Causes of the condition include amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), strokes, traumatic brain injury, neoplasm, and multiple sclerosis (as is the likely diagnosis in this patient).  

The clinical presentation of pseudobulbar palsy includes dysphagia, dysarthria, dysphonia, and an increased gag reflex. Patients may also show signs of emotional lability and apathy. Of note, while the gag reflex is exaggerated in pseudobulbar palsy (upper motor neuron lesion), it is typically absent in bulbar palsy (lower motor neuron lesion). This difference is a key clinical sign used to distinguish between bulbar and pseudobulbar palsy.  



Option Analysis

✅ Demyelination of the bilateral corticobulbar tracts:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Mass in the jugular foramen:
Incorrect: A mass in the jugular foramen can compress cranial nerves IX, X, and XI and result in bulbar palsy. Bulbar palsy can manifest with weakness in the muscles supplied by these nerves and an absent gag reflex since it is a lower motor neuron lesion. However, emotional lability (inappropriate laughter) is not seen in patients with bulbar palsy. 
❌ Tumor affecting the bilateral nucleus ambiguus :
Incorrect: The nucleus ambiguus contains the motor nuclei of cranial nerves IX, X, and XI. A lesion affecting this structure will lead to bulbar palsy, resembling pseudobulbar palsy. However, reflexes are diminished, and emotional lability is absent in patients with bulbar palsy. 
❌ Tumor affecting the right nucleus ambiguus:
Incorrect: The nucleus ambiguus contains the motor nuclei for CN IX, X, and XI. A lesion affecting this structure will lead to bulbar palsy, resembling pseudobulbar palsy. However, reflexes are diminished, and emotional lability is absent in patients with bulbar palsy. 
❌ Demyelination of the distal aspect cranial nerve IX:
Incorrect: This patient has an exaggerated gag reflex, suggestive of an upper motor neuron lesion. In contrast, demyelination of the peripheral portions of the cranial nerves outside the skull will result in lower motor neuron symptoms, such as decreased reflexes.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presents to the urgent care clinic for evaluation of tingling and numbness in both feet. For two days, both of the patient’s legs have felt heavy, and yesterday, both feet began tingling. Additionally, she did not notice she was bleeding after stubbing her left great toe until she put on her socks today. Two weeks ago, she experienced two days of vomiting and diarrhea immediately following a camping trip in the Rocky Mountains. Past medical history is noncontributory, and she takes no medications. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 14/min, blood pressure is 120/80 mmHg, and SpO2 is 99% on room air. On physical exam, there is symmetric sensory loss to sharp touch in the bilateral lower extremities to the level of the thigh. Position sense and vibration sense are impaired. Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be present?
questions.solution:
This patient presenting with rapidly progressive ascending sensory changes following exposure to a known trigger in the form of a recent gastrointestinal infection most likely has Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS). In addition to tingling, numbness, and weakness starting in the legs, patients may also report blurry or double vision, facial weakness, difficulty swallowing or speaking, shortness of breath, and various types of pain including low back pain, radicular pain, and muscle and joint pain.        

GBS represents an acute, monophasic, immune-mediated polyradiculopathy occurring one to three weeks following exposure to certain pathogens, including Cambylobacter jejuni. In addition to generalized paresis, patients can experience sensory loss, autonomic dysfunction, and respiratory failure. The most common variant is a demyelinating polyradiculopathy, but in some cases, the injury is axonal in nature; mixed symptoms are referred to as acute motor-sensory axonal neuropathy. Electrodiagnostic studies obtained within one week of symptom onset can help confirm the diagnosis.   

Option Analysis

✅ Low back pain:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Intermittent fevers:
Incorrect: Patients presenting with symptoms and signs suggestive of Guillain-Barré syndrome are typically afebrile as this condition often represents an immune-mediated delayed response to an acute infectious trigger. 
❌ Hyperreflexia:
Incorrect: Because of acute inflammatory demyelination, patients with Guillain-Barré syndrome develop hypo- or areflexia. While deep tendon reflexes may be preserved in the axonal variant, hyperreflexia suggests an alternative diagnosis. 
❌ Ingestion of homemade canned food:
Incorrect: Foodborne botulism can occur from ingesting C. botulinum spores in improperly canned foods. However, botulism typically presents as acute-onset dysphagia, symmetrically descending weakness first affecting the neck and arms, and constipation. This patient’s weakness is an ascending pattern of weakness following a gastrointestinal illness contracted during camping, which is concerning for Guillain-Barré syndrome. 
❌ Increased muscle tone:
Incorrect: This patient presents with symptoms and signs suggestive of Guillain-Barré syndrome, which results in decreased, rather than increased, muscle tone.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents to the urgent care clinic for evaluation of clumsiness. For the past week, he has been tripping, and this morning he fell getting up out of a chair. Three weeks ago, he had five days of nasal congestion, cough, and low-grade fever attributed to a viral illness. Past medical history is noncontributory, and he takes no medications. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 66/min, respirations are 16/min, blood pressure is 122/80 mmHg, and SpO2 is 100% on room air. On physical exam, respirations are nonlabored, and lungs are clear to auscultation. There is symmetric bilateral weakness with ankle dorsiflexion, knee flexion and extension, and hip flexion. Patellar deep tendon reflexes are absent. Which of the following additional diagnostic findings is most likely?
questions.solution:
This patient presenting with rapidly progressive ascending weakness following a recent viral respiratory infection most likely has Guillain-Barré syndrome. The patient has evidence of adequate respiratory functioning; therefore, the most appropriate diagnostic test is a lumbar puncture for cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis. Patients with Guillain-Barré syndrome will have an elevated protein count with a normal white blood cell count in the CSF, also known as albuminocytologic disassociation.       

However, if CSF analysis occurs very early in the disease course (within 48 hours of symptom onset), the results may be normal. Additionally, nerve conduction studies in patients with Guillain-Barré typically show a conduction delay, and electromyography (EMG) may show abnormal recruitment, an absent H-reflex, an abnormal upper extremity sensory nerve action potential, or reduced compound muscle action potential amplitude. However, these electrodiagnostic studies may also initially be normal. Therefore, if clinical suspicion is high, but results of CSF and electrodiagnostic testing are normal, the patient may be very early in the disease course, and treatment should proceed with testing repeated later in the disease course. Electrodiagnostic studies are typically performed to support the diagnosis of GBS and to provide prognostic information.   

Option Analysis

✅ Albuminocytologic disassociation:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) pleocytosis:
Incorrect: A low or normal CSF white blood cell count is seen in Guillain-Barré syndrome. Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) pleocytosis (or elevated CSF white blood cell count) suggests alternative diagnoses, like viral myelitis. 
❌ Normal nerve conduction velocity:
Incorrect: Conduction delay is observed in patients with Guillain-Barré syndrome. A normal nerve conduction velocity, especially beyond one week after symptom onset, suggests an alternative diagnosis. 
❌ Myopathic pattern on electromyography (EMG):
Incorrect: The EMG in a patient with Guillain-Barré syndrome may be normal or show evidence of muscle denervation. A myopathic pattern suggests an alternative diagnosis.  
❌ High negative inspiratory pressure:
Incorrect: Patients with impaired diaphragm function secondary to Guillain-Barré syndrome will have reduced inspiratory pressure and negative inspiratory force (NIF). A high NIF suggests an alternative diagnosis, like pulmonary edema or upper airway obstruction.

questions.text: A 41-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for evaluation of persistent left arm numbness and weakness since yesterday morning. Past medical history includes right optic neuritis two years ago with residual impaired visual acuity and an episode of right leg paresthesias that lasted for two months and then resolved last year. Current medications include gabapentin as needed for neuropathy. The patient’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 68/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mmHg. Visual acuity is 20/20 in the left eye and 20/25 in the right eye. Physical examination reveals subjective sensory loss in the left upper extremity and associated pronator drift. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain reveals a contrast-enhancing T2 hyperintense lesion in the right parietal cortex and a non-enhancing T2 hyperintense juxtacortical lesion in the left mesial frontal lobe. The patient is started on symptomatic treatment and intravenous corticosteroids. Which of the following, if prescribed, would prevent future relapses and slow disease progression?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with symptoms of an acute relapse of relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis (MS), as evidenced by the development of new neurological deficits following a period of stable neurologic disability. In addition to supportive care, treatment of MS should include high-dose corticosteroids and disease-modifying therapy, like the monoclonal antibody natalizumab, to minimize future relapses and slow disease progression.

Similar treatment strategies are used to treat relapsing-remitting and primary progressive MS. These include symptomatic treatment, injectable immunomodulators, and oral and intravenous immunosuppressants. For patients who do not tolerate corticosteroids for acute attacks, plasmapheresis serves as an alternative treatment. Symptomatic management includes medications like muscle relaxants for spasticity or stimulants for fatigue, as well as physical or occupational therapy. Patients may benefit from the use of orthotics, cognitive behavioral therapy, or alternative therapies.

Disease-modifying agents include immunomodulatory and immunosuppressive therapies. The selection depends on the type of MS, mode of administration, side effect profile, and patient preferences. Immunosuppressants are associated with an increased risk of opportunistic infections, cancer, and progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy.

Option Analysis

✅ Natalizumab:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Dalfampridine:
Incorrect: Dalfampridine may improve symptoms like the speed of walking in patients with multiple sclerosis; however, it is not a disease-modifying medication like natalizumab that will prevent future relapses and slow disease progression.
❌ Baclofen:
Incorrect: Baclofen may be used as a symptomatic treatment for spasticity related to multiple sclerosis, but it does not prevent future relapses or slow disease progression.
❌ Oral corticosteroids:
Incorrect: While high-dose intravenous corticosteroids are used to treat acute relapses, oral corticosteroids are not effective in preventing future multiple sclerosis relapses. Steroid-sparing immunomodulatory therapy is preferred.
❌ Methotrexate:
Incorrect: Methotrexate may be used in rare cases as a disease-modifying agent, but it is not considered first- or second-line therapy for preventing multiple sclerosis relapses. Natalizumab would be preferred.

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman presents to the primary care clinic for evaluation of frequent falls. For several years, the patient has experienced gradually progressive numbness and tingling in both feet, and for the past year, the patient has felt increasingly unsteady. Past medical history is significant for gastroesophageal reflux disease managed with omeprazole and over-the-counter antacids. The patient follows a vegan diet. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 118/72 mmHg. Proprioception and vibration are impaired. There is mild weakness with ankle plantar and dorsiflexion bilaterally. The patient has hyperreflexia and a wide-based gait. Which of the following findings would be expected on workup?

choices.text: Albuminocytologic dissociation in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF)

questions.solution:
This older adult patient presents with symptoms and findings concerning for polyneuropathy, including weakness, ataxia, and progressive, bilateral paresthesias. Given the later age of onset, the slowly progressive nature of the symptoms, and the historical clues (e.g., vegan diet, antacid use), vitamin B12 deficiency is the most likely diagnosis. A low vitamin B12 level is expected.

Polyneuropathies are associated with demyelination or axonal injury of multiple peripheral nerves. Possible etiologies include hereditary and acquired conditions. A family history of similar, slowly progressive symptoms suggests a hereditary cause. In contrast, rapidly progressive symptoms without a family history may indicate an acquired cause such as Guillain-Barré syndrome or critical illness polyneuropathy. Symptoms progressing over months to years in the absence of a family history suggest acquired causes like diabetic neuropathy, alcoholic neuropathy, or vitamin B12 deficiency.

In addition to the characteristics above, the pattern of symptoms and physical exam findings may point to a specific diagnosis and can guide additional testing. This can include measuring vitamin B12 levels for deficiency, hemoglobin A1c for diabetic neuropathy, CSF analysis for Guillain-Barré syndrome, genetic testing for Friedreich ataxia or Charcot-Marie-Tooth type 1a, and VLCFA levels for conditions like adrenomyeloneuropathy.

Option Analysis

✅ Low vitamin B12 level:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Frataxin gene mutation:
Incorrect: A mutation in the Frataxin gene is associated with Fredrich ataxia. However, a hereditary cause like Friedrich ataxia is unlikely in an older adult, as it typically presents in childhood or adolescence. Additionally, a vegan diet and frequent use of antacids are risk factors for vitamin B12 deficiency.
❌ PMP22 duplication:
Incorrect: A PMP22 duplication is associated with Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease type 1a (CMT1A). CMT1A typically has an onset in childhood or adolescence and is often associated with pes cavus and hammertoes bilaterally. This patient’s history of slowly progressive sensory changes, weakness, and ataxia, along with the diet and medication history, suggests vitamin B12 deficiency.
❌ Albuminocytologic dissociation in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF):
Incorrect: Guillain-Barre syndrome (GBS) is associated with albuminocytologic dissociation in the CSF. However, GBS tends to feature rapidly progressive, ascending symptoms. This patient’s history of slowly progressive sensory changes, weakness, and ataxia, along with the diet and medication history, suggests vitamin B12 deficiency.
❌ Elevated hemoglobin A1c:
Incorrect: The patient’s history of slowly progressive sensory changes, weakness, and ataxia, along with the diet and medication history, suggests vitamin B12 deficiency. Even apart from the absence of long-standing poor glucose control, diabetic neuropathy typically presents with burning pain and sensory loss in a stocking-glove distribution.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for evaluation of worsening mid back pain and numbness and tingling in both legs for the past two days. This morning, the patient tripped while going up the stairs and has felt progressively weaker throughout the day. She has not voided since the previous evening. Medical history includes multiple sclerosis managed with teriflunomide. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 118/70 mmHg. On exam, there is symmetric drift in both lower extremities and impaired proprioception, pain, temperature, and vibration sense in both legs. Upper extremity strength and sensation are normal. Which of the following tests confirms the diagnosis?

choices.text: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the thoracic spine with and without contrast
Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the cervical spine with and without contrast
Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain with and without contrast
Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the lumbosacral spine with and without contrast
Serum and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis for oligoclonal banding

questions.solution:
This patient presents with signs of a complete spinal cord syndrome, including mid-back pain, progressive bilateral lower extremity weakness, bladder dysfunction, and loss of all sensory modalities in the legs. A history of multiple sclerosis raises concern for an acute demyelinating episode, such as transverse myelitis. This diagnosis can be confirmed with MRI of the thoracic spine with and without contrast.        

The differential diagnosis for a suspected spinal cord lesion in a stable adult depends on the level of involvement (e.g., cervical or thoracic) and can be further refined by evaluating the pattern of sensory loss and the presence and distribution of weakness.        

After clinical localization, additional neurodiagnostic studies such as electromyography, nerve conduction studies, MRI, and cerebrospinal fluid analysis can help confirm the diagnosis. Careful clinical assessment before imaging can reduce unnecessary and costly testing.   

Option Analysis

✅ Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the thoracic spine with and without contrast:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the cervical spine with and without contrast:
Incorrect: Lower extremity symptoms without upper extremity involvement suggest a lesion below the cervical spinal cord. The presence of mid-back pain supports thoracic localization rather than cervical. 
❌ Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain with and without contrast:
Incorrect: A cerebral lesion would not produce isolated bilateral lower extremity weakness and complete sensory loss. The findings are more consistent with a spinal cord syndrome. 
❌ Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the lumbosacral spine with and without contrast:
Incorrect: This patient’s bilateral lower extremity loss of all sensory modalities suggests a complete cord syndrome. The accompanying mid-back pain suggests a thoracic level lesion as opposed to a lumbar lesion.  
❌ Serum and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis for oligoclonal banding:
Incorrect: While oligoclonal bands may support a diagnosis of multiple sclerosis, this test is not appropriate for the acute evaluation of spinal cord dysfunction. Immediate imaging is necessary to assess for structural or inflammatory lesions.

questions.text: A 37-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of difficulty breathing. Yesterday evening, the patient felt that his legs were heavy, and he felt tired, which he attributed to a busy day at the office. This morning, both of the patient’s legs began tingling, he felt increasingly weak, and he started tripping on the stairs. For the past few hours, the patient has felt as if he cannot catch his breath. He has no significant past medical history and takes no daily medications. Three weeks ago, he received his annual influenza vaccination. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 84/min, respirations are 14/min, blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. On physical exam, there is symmetric bilateral weakness with ankle dorsiflexion, knee flexion and extension, as well as a loss of vibration sense. Deep tendon reflexes are absent in the bilateral lower extremities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient presenting with rapidly progressive ascending weakness affecting breathing following exposure to a known trigger (e.g. seasonal influenza vaccination) likely has Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) with difficulty breathing. The first step in assessment of a patient suspected of having GBS is to stabilize the airway, breathing, and circulation, which may require endotracheal intubation and mechanical ventilation. If patients are able to perform bedside pulmonary function testing, it can assess breathing ability and guide respiratory management.     

GBS is an immune-mediated polyradiculoneuropathy that may result in diaphragm weakness, which can quickly progress to respiratory failure. A forced vital capacity (FVC) measures the amount of air a patient can exhale after a maximum inhalation and may be reduced in a patient with neuromuscular weakness. Similarly, negative inspiratory force may be reduced as well, and there may be reduced maximal expiratory pressure.       

Hypoxemia is a late finding in respiratory distress and suggests impending respiratory failure in patients with GBS. As such, pulse oximetry or arterial oxygen levels should not be relied on to guide respiratory management in patients with GBS.   

Option Analysis

✅ Bedside pulmonary function testing:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Chest radiography:
Incorrect: While chest radiography can show evidence of poor inspiratory effort and abnormal lung volumes, it is not a reliable way to measure inspiratory volume. In a patient suspected of having significant neuromuscular weakness, a more objective assessment of respiratory function is needed to guide management. 
❌ Respiratory viral panel :
Incorrect: A respiratory viral panel can identify an underlying viral cause of immune-mediated polyradiculopathy, but the immediate management of a patient suspected of having neuromuscular weakness with respiratory involvement includes assessment of respiratory function and stabilization of the airway if the patient is unstable or has abnormal respiratory functioning. 
❌ Arterial oxygen monitoring:
Incorrect: Peripheral and arterial oxygen saturations are often normal in patients with neuromuscular weakness; hypoxemia is typically seen as a late finding. Arterial oxygen level measurement is invasive and should not be used to guide immediate respiratory management in patients with Guillain-Barré syndrome and difficulty breathing. 
❌ Intravenous corticosteroids:
Incorrect: Corticosteroids have not been shown to reduce disease severity or duration of symptoms in patients with Guillain-Barré syndrome, and their use may lead to adverse effects.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman presents to the ophthalmologist for evaluation of vision changes in the left eye. The patient was painting in her art studio two days ago when she noticed that red hues appeared “washed out” or lighter in her left eye. As the day progressed, she developed blurry vision in the left eye. She has no refractive error in either eye and does not wear corrective lenses. Past medical history is notable for vitamin D deficiency for which she takes a daily supplement. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 120/72 mmHg. Visual acuity is 20/20 in the right eye and 20/50 in the left eye. Examination reveals failure of both pupils to constrict when the light is shown in the left eye. There is no conjunctival erythema. Fundoscopic evaluation reveals subtle disc edema and pallor of the left optic nerve. The right optic nerve appears normal. The remainder of the cranial nerve examination is unremarkable. The patient has normal strength and reflexes bilaterally in the upper and lower extremities. Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be present?

choices.text: Improvement of symptoms with a hot shower

questions.solution:
This patient presents with acute-onset monocular vision loss and red desaturation. Physical examination reveals unilateral decreased visual acuity, optic disc pallor, and a relative afferent pupillary defect consistent with optic neuritis. Patients with optic neuritis often experience pain with eye movements in the affected eye.

While this condition can occur due to other diseases, optic neuritis can often be the first clinical episode consistent with a demyelinating etiology suggestive of multiple sclerosis (MS). MS is an autoimmune condition characterized by demyelinating central nervous system lesions (CNS). Other symptoms of MS include double vision, dysarthria, numbness, weakness, incoordination, vertigo, and dysautonomia. Risk factors for MS include female biological sex, younger age, previous Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection, vitamin D deficiency, tobacco use, and increased geographical distance from the equator. Examination findings may include internuclear ophthalmoplegia, dysarthria, sensory loss, weakness, spasticity, ataxia, and hyperreflexia. Mimics of this condition include acute ischemic stroke, CNS infections, encephalitis, spinal cord pathology, and other demyelinating lesions.

Option Analysis

✅ Pain with left eye movements:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Retinal hemorrhage:
Incorrect: Retinal hemorrhages are suggestive of vascular disease, infection, retinal detachment, or ocular trauma. They do not occur with optic neuritis. This patient presents with symptoms and findings consistent with optic neuritis of the left eye and pain with movements of the affected eye would be expected.
❌ Improvement of symptoms with a hot shower:
Incorrect: This patient presents with symptoms and findings consistent with optic neuritis of the left eye. Temporary worsening of visual symptoms (not improvement) often occurs in patients with optic neuritis with exposure to heat (i.e., after exercise, taking a hot shower). This is known as the Uhthoff phenomenon.
❌ Excessive lacrimation:
Incorrect: Patients with corneal or conjunctival irritation or abrasions may present with excessive lacrimation. This patient has no evidence of corneal irritation and has findings consistent with optic neuritis. Patients with optic neuritis often experience pain with movements of the affected eye.
❌ Cotton wool spots:
Incorrect: Cotton wool spots (i.e. white, fluffy patches overlying the retina) are associated with diabetes, hypertension, and human immunodeficiency virus (HIV). They are not associated with optic neuritis.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the urgent care clinic for evaluation of persistent right arm numbness and tingling for one day and blurry vision in the right eye. There is no associated weakness. She has had no recent trauma, fever, or constitutional symptoms. Past medical history is notable for an episode of left optic neuritis 2 years ago that was treated with intravenous corticosteroids. She does not take any medications. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 82/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 118/70 mmHg. Fundoscopic examination reveals right optic disc pallor. She is unable to fully adduct the right eye and has nystagmus. There are subjective sensory changes in the right upper extremity with intact strength and reflexes. Brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) shows an area of hyperintensity in the left parietal juxtacortical region. Which of the following additional diagnostic tests is necessary to confirm the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with symptoms and physical examination findings that are concerning for multiple sclerosis (MS) according to the McDonald criteria, which are outlined in the table below. These criteria are used for diagnosing MS and require that a patient have new, unexplained neurological symptoms for >24 hours duration accompanied by radiographic evidence of dissemination in space, in the setting of a history of a prior episode of demyelination. The presence of cerebrospinal fluid-specific oligoclonal bands demonstrating intrathecal production of immunoglobulin G would confirm the diagnosis of MS.

In a patient with symptoms and signs concerning for MS, the first diagnostic test to obtain is a brain magnetic resonance image (MRI) with intravenous (IV) contrast. This test will evaluate for the presence of a T2 hyperintense lesion in either the periventricular, cortical, juxtacortical, infratentorial regions or in the spinal cord. Variable contrast enhancement between lesions establishes evidence of dissemination in time. Next, lumbar puncture with CSF analysis should be performed. The finding of CSF-specific oligoclonal bands confirms the diagnosis of MS.

Once the diagnosis is made using MRI and CSF analysis, the pattern of symptom progression should be determined. A pattern of stable neurologic disability between episodes indicates a relapsing-remitting presentation, which is the most common type of disease progression. Patients with progressive disability independent of relapses can be diagnosed with primary progressive MS. Some patients with relapsing-remitting patterns may develop progressive neurologic decline, representing secondary progressive MS.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Nerve conduction velocity:
Incorrect: This patient presents with unexplained neurological symptoms and a history of a previous demyelination event concerning multiple sclerosis. Nerve conduction studies are typically normal in patients with MS, but when they are abnormal, they are not specific for MS. CSF analysis can confirm the diagnosis if CSF-specific oligoclonal bands are present.
❌ Visual evoked potentials:
Incorrect: This patient presents with unexplained neurological symptoms and a history of a previous demyelination event concerning multiple sclerosis. Visual evoked potentials may be abnormal in an acute episode of optic neuritis, but an abnormal result is not specific for multiple sclerosis. Evidence of CSF-specific immunoglobulin production is necessary to confirm the diagnosis.
❌ Carotid artery ultrasound:
Incorrect: This patient presents with unexplained neurological symptoms and a history of a previous demyelination event concerning multiple sclerosis. Carotid artery imaging is part of the diagnostic workup for an acute ischemic stroke, but in the case of stroke, a brain MRI would show a wedge-shaped infarct as opposed to the juxtacortical lesion in this case, which is more consistent with MS. Evidence of CSF-specific immunoglobulin production is necessary to confirm the diagnosis of MS.
❌ Electroencephalography:
Incorrect: Focal paresthesias can be a result of epileptic phenomena that are typically transient and can be diagnosed by electroencephalography. However, this patient’s symptoms are persistent and progressive, and the MRI is suggestive of demyelination; therefore, CSF testing is indicated next to confirm the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 37-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of bilateral leg weakness for one day. The patient’s legs feel heavy, and there has been increasing difficulty walking, including tripping on stairs. For the past few hours, he has also had shortness of breath. There is no significant medical history, and no daily medications are used. Immunizations are up to date, including the annual influenza vaccine, which was administered three weeks ago. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 84/min, respirations are 14/min, blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. On exam, there is symmetric bilateral weakness with ankle dorsiflexion, knee flexion and extension, and a loss of vibration sense. Deep tendon reflexes are absent in both lower extremities. Which of the following tests is most appropriate to obtain?

choices.text: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the lumbar spine

questions.solution:
This patient presents three weeks after receiving the influenza vaccine with acute-onset, rapidly ascending bilateral weakness consistent with acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy, the most common variant of Guillain-Barré syndrome. Because respiratory muscles can become involved early in the disease course, prompt assessment of pulmonary function using forced vital capacity or negative inspiratory force is essential.

The acute management of a patient with new-onset weakness begins with stabilization of the airway, breathing, and circulation. Continuous monitoring of vital signs, including blood pressure, heart rate, oxygen saturation, and cardiac rhythm, is critical while further diagnostic evaluation and treatment are underway. Intravenous (IV) access should be established, and IV fluids administered as needed. Intubation and mechanical ventilation may be required, particularly in patients with Guillain-Barré syndrome or those with high cervical spinal cord lesions, due to involvement of the phrenic nerves.

Option Analysis

✅ Forced vital capacity:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Lumbar puncture:
Incorrect: Cerebrospinal fluid analysis may support a diagnosis of Guillain-Barré syndrome, but this test should not precede assessment of respiratory status in an individual with signs of neuromuscular weakness.
❌ Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the lumbar spine:
Incorrect: Spinal imaging may be considered to evaluate for causes such as cord compression or transverse myelitis, but it should not delay evaluation of respiratory function in suspected Guillain-Barré syndrome.
❌ Electromyogram:
Incorrect: Electromyography can prove helpful in the diagnosis of rapidly ascending bilateral lower extremity weakness but are not immediately necessary and should not delay respiratory monitoring.
❌ Computerized tomography (CT) of the head:
Incorrect: Neuroimaging of the head may be appropriate in a patient with repeated falls; however, this patient’s rapidly ascending bilateral lower extremity weakness is concerning for Guillain-Barré syndrome, which may impair respiration. Respiratory status should be assessed with forced vital capacity.

questions.text: A 66-year-old woman presents to the primary care clinic for evaluation of numbness. There has been persistent numbness in all four extremities for the past two months, along with difficulty rising from a chair. Medical history is notable for hypertension, managed with lisinopril. There is no recent history of trauma, vaccination, or infection. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 130/85 mmHg. The patient appears alert. Cranial nerve examination is normal. Vibration sense is impaired in all four extremities, but pain and temperature sensation are intact. Muscle strength is decreased in the distal lower extremities. Gait is wide-based and unsteady, particularly with the eyes closed. Which of the following additional historical findings is most likely to be present?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with progressive bilateral loss of vibration sense, gait instability, and lower extremity weakness, suggesting involvement of both the dorsal columns and lateral corticospinal tracts. These findings are characteristic of subacute combined degeneration due to vitamin B12 deficiency. A strict vegan diet is a common cause, making this the most likely historical finding.        

Spinal cord lesions often present with bilateral motor or sensory deficits below a specific level. Localization begins by identifying whether there is weakness or sensory loss in the cervical and/or thoracic regions. The pattern of sensory loss helps determine which spinal tracts are affected. Impaired vibration and proprioception suggest dorsal column dysfunction, often accompanied by a positive Romberg sign or a stomping, wide-based gait. The presence of lower extremity weakness, particularly with spasticity, points to additional involvement of the lateral corticospinal tracts.        

This specific combination of findings should prompt evaluation for causes of subacute combined degeneration, including vitamin B12 deficiency. Common causes of vitamin B12 deficiency include a strict vegan diet, malabsorption (e.g., inflammatory bowel disease, gastric bypass), or B12 inactivation (e.g. recreational inhalation of nitrous oxide).   

Option Analysis

✅ A strict vegan diet:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Remote untreated syphilis infection:
Incorrect: Tabes dorsalis from neurosyphilis may cause dorsal column dysfunction, resulting in impaired vibration and proprioception. However, it typically does not cause motor weakness. The presence of both sensory and motor findings suggests subacute combined degeneration from vitamin B12 deficiency.  
❌ Aortic disease:
Incorrect: Posterior spinal cord infarction from aortic disease typically presents acutely and may result in bilateral sensory loss as a result of dorsal column involvement. However, the presence of weakness suggests subacute combined degeneration from vitamin B12 deficiency. 
❌ Family history of similar symptoms:
Incorrect: Hereditary ataxias can present with dorsal column involvement and gait disturbance, but they usually have an earlier onset and a more slowly progressive course. The subacute onset in this older patient favors an acquired, reversible cause. 
❌ History of optic neuritis:
Incorrect: A history of optic neuritis raises concern for demyelinating disorders such as multiple sclerosis or neuromyelitis optica. These conditions often involve the anterior cord and tend to present with relapsing episodes, not a subacute progressive course limited to dorsal column and motor tract involvement.

questions.text: A 61-year-old woman is hospitalized for new-onset weakness. Two days ago, she said that both of her feet began tingling and her legs began feeling weak. These symptoms rapidly worsened yesterday resulting in a fall and prompting an evaluation in the emergency department. Past medical history is noncontributory, and she takes no medications. She received routine immunizations three weeks ago. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 78/min, respirations are 14/min, blood pressure is 130/84 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. On physical exam, there is symmetric bilateral lower extremity weakness and sensory loss with absent deep tendon reflexes. A bedside forced vital capacity is normal. A diagnostic lumbar puncture shows an elevated cerebrospinal fluid protein level and normal white blood cell count. Electrodiagnostic studies show conduction delay and a denervation pattern. In addition to supportive care, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with rapidly progressive ascending weakness following exposure to a known trigger with confirmatory diagnostic testing for Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS). Treatment is with immunomodulatory therapy, either intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) or plasma exchange.        

In addition to immunomodulatory therapy, patients with GBS should have supportive care. This includes respiratory support with frequent reassessment of respiratory function with bedside pulmonary function tests. Patients should initially be monitored for worsening symptoms with serial neurologic examinations performed daily. Some patients may have labile blood pressure, arrhythmias, and other signs of cardiovascular compromise from dysautonomia, which requires monitoring and possibly other management strategies. Due to reduced mobility, preventative measures should include deep vein thrombosis prophylaxis and pressure ulcer prevention measures. Consultation with physical and occupational therapy helps with early rehabilitation to prevent deconditioning. Finally, some patients may require pain management.        

Option Analysis

✅ Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG):
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Intravenous corticosteroids:
Incorrect: Corticosteroids have not been shown to reduce disease severity or duration in patients with Guillain-Barré syndrome and may lead to adverse effects. 
❌ Botulism antitoxin:
Incorrect: Foodborne botulism as a result of ingestion of C. botulinum spores may cause descending weakness, first affecting the neck and arms. This patient’s weakness is in an ascending pattern consistent with Guillain-Barré syndrome, which should be treated with IVIG. 
❌ Intravenous broad-spectrum antibiotics:
Incorrect: Guillain-Barré syndrome represents an immune-mediated – rather than primary infectious – process that often occurs in response to a viral or other antigenic trigger. Treatment is with immunomodulatory therapy rather than with antimicrobial therapy. 
❌ Intravenous anti-hypertensives:
Incorrect: While patients with Guillain-Barré syndrome may display evidence of cardiovascular instability secondary to dysautonomia, the blood pressure is often labile, and use of antihypertensives may cause hypotension. Definitive treatment is with immunomodulatory therapy.
